item.title: New Yell System - Filter and Timers
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“Team_Rocket, post:16, topic:466692”][quote author=asshole_rule link=topic=583626.msg4201378#msg4201378 date=1358250114]

[quote author=Team_Rocket link=topic=583626.msg4201359#msg4201359 date=1358247391]

use

for(Player p : PlayerHandler.players) if(p != null) Client c2 = p;
[/quote][/quote]

That doesn’t have any effect on performance.

Just one is “prettier”, but I would go with it, just saying, it’s more of a preference.

Why would you want to Loop though? There’s no need.

How else do you expect to send the message to everyone online…

There are multiple ways of doing this. Specific Client selection is a good example. This might come as a shock to you, but there’s a different world of Java outside of RuneScape Private Servers.[/quote]
Oreally. RSPS is in Java… java can’t become another thing…

item.title: New Yell System - Filter and Timers
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“relexlawl, post:38, topic:466692”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=583626.msg4202582#msg4202582 date=1358443366]
Only problem with that is that you’re using a primitive data type, not a class such as a “Player”. An array of Players would actually take quite a bit more memory, and likely would be slightly slower.

Anyway, thanks for doing the testing to prove him wrong. I don’t have a single RSPS on my computer, cba to download a shitty one to prove my point.
[/quote]

Stop changing your argument…Look back on your previous posts…My god, you’re either really ignorant or just plain moronic.

Also why the hell would you, in an rsps, loop through an array with a size of 10,000,000? Which I also NEVER said in that case, I said in a case like this one, where it won’t be looping through more than ~2000. Please use common sense.[/quote]
You’re fucking retarded.
I said it had 2000 indexes = array[2000];. I looped through it ONE million times for more trials.
I’m fucking done with you. Go get a fucking IQ test and leave these forums until your brain develops further. You are literally so incompetent that I’m suggesting you enroll in a preschool for mentally retarded toddlers.

Read full topic

item.source: New Yell System - Filter and Timers

item.title: New Yell System - Filter and Timers
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

I ran this:

[code=Java]public class Main
{

static int players[] = new int[2000];
static long startTime;

public static void main(String args[])
{
	startTime = System.currentTimeMillis();
	for(int fl = 0; fl < players.length; fl++)
	{
		yell("hi " + fl);
	}
	System.out.println("FOR: 2000 iterations completed in: " + (System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime) + "ms.");
}

static void yell(String msg)
{
	@SuppressWarnings("unused") int useless = (msg + " hi").length();
}

}[/code]

and this:

[code=Java]public class Main
{

static int players[] = new int[2000];
static long startTime;

public static void main(String args[])
{
	startTime = System.currentTimeMillis();
	for(int fe : players)
	{
		yell("hi " + fe);
	}
	System.out.println("FOREACH: 2000 iterations completed in: " + (System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime) + "ms.");		
}

static void yell(String msg)
{
	@SuppressWarnings("unused") int useless = (msg + " hi").length();
}

}[/code]

30 tests with the for loop and only once was it under 10ms, 30 tests with the foreach loop and it was 8ms six times and the rest ranged from 9-13ms. Also note that if this code was executed 15 minutes into the server’s runtime, it would be a lot quicker due to the fact that the JVM had been fully initialised (put the contents of both main() methods into one method and you’ll see that the one which is executed second will perform 2000 iterations in 1-3ms, always)

Read full topic
item.source: New Yell System - Filter and Timers

item.title: New Yell System - Filter and Timers
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

relaxlawl, I NEVER said PI was a viable source for benchmarking. Please quote the post where I said this.

Here is the output averaged from 10 million trials of a foreach vs for loop of an array with 10000 indexes.

Foreach: 7.37 ns For: 8.04 ns
As you can see the number is still quite minuscule. I never claimed that you should be using a foreach instead of a for loop, only that one has slightly better performance (which at these times, should not even matter).

However, when doing math in each of these loops, the foreach is actually slower:

Foreach: 7.71 ns For: 7.69 ns
Same amount of trials, same indexes, etc.

Also, I never said PI would take 5 seconds per tick. I said PI would take 5 seconds to update per tick based on what you were saying, proving you false. Also, you just called yourself an idiot.

Read full topic
